data.title: Hall of Fame Class of 2005 announced
data.meta_description:
July 12, 2005Slippery Rock, Pa. - 
Three All-America performers will headline a group of seven inductees who will comprise the Class of 2005 in the Slippery Rock
data.text:
July 12, 2005

Slippery Rock, Pa. - Three All-America performers will headline a group of seven inductees who will comprise the Class of 2005 in the Slippery Rock University Athletic Hall of Fame.

Induction ceremonies for the 22nd group of honorees will be held Saturday, Sept. 10, as part of The Rock's home football game against Shepherd (W. Va.) University.

The latest group of inductees includes All-America performers Joan Anderson (SRU Class of 1995; cross country, track and field), Greg Hopkins (SRU Class of 1995; football, wrestling, track and field) and Jay Wagner (SRU Class of 1970/1973; football).

The Class of 2005 also includes Bill Kelly (SRU Class of 1965; football), Bill Miller (SRU Class of 1964/1972; swimming) and former Rock coaches Steve Banjak (men's gymnastics) and Dr. Al Schmittlein (golf).

In addition to the seven inductees, The Rock's 1972-74 football coaching staff will be spotlighted for a Special Recognition Award. That staff included head coach Bob DiSpirito and assistant coaches Paul Bruno, Doug Clinger, Stan Kendziorski, Rod Oberlin and Mike Pariseau.

The Hall of Fame induction ceremony will be held in the Multi-Purpose Room of the University Union on the SRU campus and will start at 3:30 p.m. with a social hour, followed by a 4:30 p.m. dinner and induction ceremonies after dinner. The Class of 2005 will also be recognized at halftime of the home football game kicking off at 7 p.m.

Banquet tickets must be purchased in advance by contacting the SRU Athletic Department in Morrow Field House at 724-738-2021. The $30 ticket also includes reserved admission to the SRU home football game that evening.

The following are highlights of the members of the Class of 2005:

Joan L. Anderson

Joan Anderson, a 1995 graduate from SRU, earned three All-America honors and competed in four NCAA national competitions as a cross country runner at The Rock.

A four-year letterwinner in cross country and three-year letterwinner in track and field, she also earned a berth in the NCAA outdoor track and field national championships and was the PSAC Women's Athlete of the Year in 1995.

In the classroom, Anderson earned GTE/CoSIDA Academic All-America and NCAA all-academic honors and received the Charles Brooker Scholarship Award for Exercise Science.

Following graduation from SRU, Anderson, a graduate of Lakeview High School in Stoneboro, attended graduate school at The Rock and the ITT Technical Institute.

Anderson also served as a track and field (1996-2002) and cross country (1998-2000) coach at Mercer High School. She served as head track and field coach from 2001-02 and as head cross country coach from 1998-2000. She helped lead Mercer to three successive conference cross country championships and a pair of PIAA state berths in track and field.

Anderson currently works as business manager for Orthovision Brace & Surgical and sales consultant for AcuStep Foot Orthotics, both of which are based in Mercer.

Stephen J. Banjak

Steve Banjak compiled a .576 winning percentage (114-84) against primarily NCAA Division I opponents in 16 seasons (1968-84) as SRU's men's gymnastics coach.

Banjak's Rock teams enjoyed 11 winning seasons and recorded 10 top-four league finishes under his tutelage. He also coached 10 league individual champions, five NCAA Division II All-America performers and led SRU to a sixth-place finish in the 1981-82 NCAA D-II national championships.

Another high-water mark of Banjak's career came in 1975 when SRU won the Great Lakes Intercollegiate Gymnastic League (GLIGL) team championship. He was named as the league's "Coach of Year" that season.

In addition to his coaching duties at SRU, Banjak was one of the founders of the GLIGL in 1973 and the West Penn Gymnastic Club in the early 1970s, spent a pair of sabbatical leaves assisting colleagues in the Slovak Republic (formerly Czechoslovakia) and served 16 years as Director of Men for Sokol USA.

A native of Farrell and a 1960 graduate of the University of Iowa, Banjak coached and taught in the West Mifflin Area School District before accepting The Rock's coaching reins.

Greg Hopkins

Greg Hopkins, currently one of the top players in the Arena Football League, was a four-year letterman and three-time All-America and All-Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference selection as a member of The Rock football team. He also earned GTE/CoSIDA Academic All-America honors as a senior.

A 1995 graduate of SRU, Hopkins also earned two letters and an alternate berth to the NCAA Division I national tournament in wrestling and secured a PSAC Championships berth in his only season on The Rock outdoor track and field team.

Hopkins remains The Rock's all-time leader in pass receptions (215), pass receiving yards (3,382) and pass receiving touchdowns (28).

A 10-year veteran of the Arena Football League, Hopkins has earned a pair of All-Arena honors. He received the league's top individual honor, "Ironman of the Year," in 2002 and holds the league career record for interceptions returned for a touchdown with eight.

A native of Nineveh and 1990 graduate of Waynesburg High School, Hopkins is a member of the AFL Players Association's executive board. He has also served as Morris Township Auditor and acting president of the township's community center committee.

William V. Kelly

Bill Kelly was a four-year letterwinner in football at The Rock. He served two seasons as a team co-captain, earned one All-Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference honor and was named as the team MVP as a senior in 1964.

Kelly's playing career was interrupted by a two-year stint in the U.S. Army, followed by a one-year hiatus due to a serious injury sustained during preseason workouts in 1963 (which would have been his senior season).

Kelly's return to The Rock in 1964 was an illustrious one, as he was named as a team co-captain and earned All-PSAC and team MVP honors.

Following graduation from SRU in 1965, Kelly was a teacher in the Pittsburgh Public Schools system and a regional manager for the Gulf Oil Corporation.

Kelly, who died suddenly in 1975 at the age of 35, was a 1957 graduate of Perry High School in Pittsburgh.

Sean Patrick Kelly, the son of Bill and Gretchen Moran Kelly, graduated from SRU in 1999 with a bachelor's degree in history.

William G. Miller

Bill Miller, a member of SRU's Class of 1964, was a self-proclaimed "slightly better than average swimmer" at The Rock. But his success as a collegiate swimming coach was considerably better than average.

Miller coached the Clarion University men's team for 22 seasons and the Golden Eagles women's team for 13 seasons before retiring in 2000. His teams won 80 percent of their dual meets (244 wins in 302 meets), 28 Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference team championships and 23 top-five finishes in the NCAA Division II national meet.

CU men's teams had a 154-38 dual-meet record, won 16 PSAC titles and garnered 12 top-five national finishes under Miller's guidance. The Golden Eagles won 11 straight PSAC titles from 1970 to 1989 and were national runners-up in 1992..

Miller led the Clarion women to a 90-20 dual-meet record, 12 PSAC titles and 11 top-five national finishes, highlighted by a national runner-up honor in 1993.

In recognition of his coaching prowess, Miller was named as the PSAC "Coach of the Year" a total of 13 times (seven women's, six men's). He was also selected as the NCAA Division II men's "Coach of the Year" in 1992, the same year in which he received the Steadman Award from the College Swimming Coaches Association of America in recognition of his contribution to the sport of swimming nationally.

Prior to becoming Clarion's head coach, Miller coached at Seneca Valley (where his teams won four section and one WPIAL titles) and Norwin high schools.

Miller is a former member of the NCAA Swimming Rules Committee, as well as chair for NCAA Division II Swimming (1981-85), CSCAA board member and Officials Coordinator for the Division I National Championships.

Miller and his wife, Judith, currently own and operate the Clarion House Bed and Breakfast. Among his civic activities, Miller has served as president of Choice Enterprises, a non-profit company that finds homes and employment for people with mental handicaps; as a Clarion borough councilman and board member of the Clarion University Credit Union and Western Pennsylvania Bed and Breakfast Association.

Miller is a 1959 graduate of Butler High School.

Albert E. Schmittlein, PhD

Al Schmittlein was The Rock's head golf coach from 1979 to 1992 after serving several seasons as an assistant coach on the staff of former athletic director and head golf coach Dr. Bob Raymond (SRU Athletic Hall of Fame Class of 2000).

Schmittlein guided The Rock linksters to three Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference championships (1985, 1987, 1988) and NCAA Division II postseason competition eight straight years (1985 to 1992).

Among the players coached by Schmittlein were first-team All-America selections Jim Hagstrom (1986) and Gordon Vietmeier (1990).

A 1976 graduate of the Professional Golf Association's School for Teaching Golf, Schmittlein served several seasons as the NCAA Division II rankings committee for the Golf Coaches Association of America.

Away from the links, Schmittlein served as a Dean of the School of Arts & Sciences and as an English professor at SRU. He was named as Professor Laureate in 1964 and Outstanding Professor or English in 1977.

Schmittlein also served as the University's first Director of Public Relations and as Director of Liberal Arts.

Schmittlein received both his bachelor's (1950) and Ph.D. (1962) degrees from the University of Pittsburgh and earned a master's degree in comparative literature from Columbia University in 1953. He is also a 1944 graduate of Allegheny High School in Pittsburgh.

He began his teaching career as a public school teacher at Franklin Township High School and in the Butler School District.

Jay Wagner

Jay Wagner was a three-year letterman in football at The Rock and culminated his playing career as an honorable mention NAIA All-America selection as a senior in 1969.

During his Rock career, Wagner also earned a pair of ECAC, NAIA all-district and All-Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference honors.

Wagner was a team captain in his final collegiate campaign.

He was The Rock's leading rusher in both his junior and senior seasons, the team's top pass receiver and kickoff return specialist as a senior and second leading receiver as a junior.

His 910 yards rushing in 1968 was among the top 20 totals in the nation that season and, at the time, ranked as the best single-season total in Rock football history. He also held the school records for career rushing (1,764 yards) and single-game rushing (236 vs. Clarion in 1968) at the conclusion of his Rock career.

Following his Rock career, Wagner received contract offers from the Buffalo Bills and New York Jets of the National Football League.

Wagner retired at the end of the 2004-05 academic year after 35 years as a fifth grade teacher in the Moniteau School District. During that time, he also coached football, track and field and golf at Moniteau, as well as youth basketball and baseball.

A 1966 graduate of Cambria Heights High School, Wagner received both his bachelor (1970) and master (1973) degrees from SRU.

Wagner is a former member of the Eau Claire borough council and parks and recreation commission.

Football coaching staff 1972-74

The first-ever Special Recognition Award will be presented to the five men who comprised The Rock football coaching staff during the 1972, 1973 and 1974 seasons.

During that three-year time span, The Rock captured three straight Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference championships and compiled a 24-5-1 won-lost record.

The induction of the Class of 2005 will increase to 144 the number of former student-athletes, coaches, administrators or supporters who have been inducted into the SRU Athletic Hall of Fame since its inception in 1984.
